ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I really enjoyed the class and the readings. Sometimes the assignments can be a bit unclear (including the final paper), but Wallace is really helpful if you go to him with questions. If the topics on the syllabus are interesting to you, you'll get a lot out of taking this class.
Highly recommend for those interested in democratization and development. Do not take if you cannot stand poli sci papers, as you will read a lot of them and some will be quite dense.

Great seminar, not too difficult, but I found it very interesting. You get a theoretical/quantitative view, and for me it was the first time encountering more academic and quantitative works on a regular basis and in such large quantities. Readings are fairly manageable--you are expected to understand the argument and the evidence in each piece, and be able to engage with it, but there isn't a need to do really really deep reading.Each week's readings are like a dialogue between different scholars. Discussions are led by students, which can be nerve-wracking but it's also great for learning about one aspect of democratization (or lack thereof) very well. Clearly this is a really broad topic but I feel like I've gotten a pretty good preliminary grasp on it so far.

I would definitely recommend this class to another student. The class is small-ish (about 15 students) so the discussions are always great. Professor Wallace is an amazing professor who's knowledge, especially in terms of Chinese politics, shines in class. He does a great job of adding to discussion without becoming a lecturer. The work in the class centers around some very interesting readings (100 pgs. a week max) and writing on a class blog (3 times for the semester). Students are also required to lead a week of discussion which allows you to learn a lot about the readings. The final is pretty standard for seminars (15 pg. essay) and Professor Wallace is always available for help during office hours. Overall a great class for those wishing to learn about dictatorships, definitely recommend.
Yes, especially if the student likes discussions led by peers.
